qas.question: What mainland was the British Isles once connected to?
What happened to British Isles area when the ice melted after the last ice age?
When sea levels rose what occured in the British Isles area?
When did the British Isles area become separated from the European continent?
Did Britain become populated with people again before or after the ice came to an end?
During the start of the first ice age, the British Isles were connected to which continent as a mass of land?
When sea levels rose, Scotlan was separated from what other country to create the Isle of Man?
Nearly 6 millennia later, what did Great Britain separate from?
After it was already a continent, Ireland probably became settled by what?

plausible_answers.text: Scotland, most of Ireland and Wales, and the hills of northern England

qas.question: Which countries were covered almost entirely by coastlines?

context: At the end of the last ice age, what are now the British Isles were joined to the <a0_0><b5_0>Europe<b5_0/>an mainland<a0_0/> as a mass of land extending north west from the modern-day northern coastline of France, Belgium and the Netherlands. Ice covered almost all of what is now <b9_0>Scotland, most of Ireland and Wales, and the hills of northern England<b9_0/>. From 14,000 to 10,000 years ago, as the ice melted, <a1_0>sea levels rose<a1_0/> <a2_0>separating Ireland from <b6_0>Great Britain<b6_0/><a2_0/> and also creating the Isle of Man. About <a3_0>two to four millennia<a3_0/> later, Great Britain became separated from <b7_0>the mainland.<b7_0/> Britain probably became repopulated with people <a4_0>before the ice age ended<a4_0/> and certainly before it became separated from the mainland. It is likely that Ireland became settled by <b8_0>sea<b8_0/> after it had already become an island.
